meta_description: Redirect to User guide
FlyteFlyte is a free and open source platform that provides a full suite of powerful features for orchestrating AI workflows. Flyte empowers AI development …
As we saw in Getting started, you can run any Python function as a task in Flyte just by decorating it with @env.task.
In many applications, different tasks within your workflow may require different configurations. Flyte enables you to manage this complexity by allowing …
Triggers allow you to automate and parameterize an execution by scheduling its start time and providing overrides for its task inputs.
The pod_template parameter in TaskEnvironment (and in the @env.task decorator, if you are overriding) allows you to customize the Kubernetes pod specification …
Flyte secrets enable you to securely store and manage sensitive information, such as API keys, passwords, and other credentials. Secrets reside in a secret …
Task resources specify the computational limits and requests (CPU, memory, GPU, storage) that will be allocated to each task’s container during execution.
Flyte provides robust error handling through configurable retry strategies and timeout controls. These parameters help ensure task reliability and prevent …
The image parameter of the TaskEnvironment is used to specify a container image. Every task defined using that TaskEnvironment will run in a container based …
By default, each task execution in Flyte and Union runs in a fresh container instance that is created just for that execution and then discarded. With …
Flyte 2 provides intelligent task output caching that automatically avoids redundant computation by reusing previously computed task results.
This section covers the essential programming patterns and techniques for developing robust Flyte workflows. Once you understand the basics of task …
The @flyte.trace decorator provides fine-grained observability and resumption capabilities for functions called within your Flyte workflows. Traces are used …
One of the key features of Flyte 2 is the ability to recover from user-level errors in a workflow execution. This includes out-of-memory errors and other …
Groups are an organizational feature in Flyte that allow you to logically cluster related task invocations (called “actions”) for better visualization and …
By default, return values in Python are materialized - meaning the actual data is downloaded and loaded into memory. This applies to simple types like …
Flyte provides the flyte.io. File and flyte.io. Dir types to represent files and directories, respectively. Together with flyte.io. DataFrame they constitute …
Dataclasses and Pydantic models are fully supported in Flyte as materialized data types: Structured data where the full content is serialized and passed …
Custom context provides a mechanism for implicitly passing configuration and metadata through your entire task execution hierarchy without adding parameters …
Flyte is designed to scale effortlessly, allowing you to run workflows with large fan-outs. When you need to execute many tasks in parallel—such as processing …
Flyte is designed to work seamlessly with Jupyter notebooks, allowing you to write and execute workflows directly within a notebook environment.
The reports feature allows you to display and update custom output in the UI during task execution.
Flyte 2 represents a substantial change from Flyte 1. While the static graph execution model will soon be available and will mirror Flyte 1 almost exactly, …
Flyte 2 represents a fundamental shift in how workflows are written and executed in Flyte.
The shift to an asynchronous model in Flyte 2 is driven by the need for more efficient and flexible workflow execution.
Flyte 2 introduces a new way of writing workflows that is based on pure Python, removing the constraints of a domain-specific language (DSL) and enabling full …
Automated migration from Flyte 1 to Flyte 2 is coming soon.
This section gives you a quick introduction to writing and running workflows on Union and Flyte 2.
Flyte SDK lets you seamlessly switch between running your workflows locally on your machine and running them remotely on your Union/Flyte instance.
In this section we will explain the options for configuring the flyte CLI and SDK to connect to your Union/Flyte instance.
To understand how Flyte 2 works, it helps to establish a few definitions and concepts.

Flyte is designed to be highly extensible and can be customized in multiple ways.
Connectors are stateless, long‑running services that receive execution requests via gRPC and then submit work to external (or internal) systems. Each …
Flyte is designed to be extensible, allowing you to integrate new tools and frameworks into your workflows. By installing and configuring plugins, you can …
Flyte can execute Dask jobs natively on a Kubernetes Cluster, which manages a cluster’s lifecycle, spin-up, and tear down. It leverages the open-sourced Dask …
Flyte can execute distributed PyTorch jobs (which is similar to Running a torchrun script) natively on a Kubernetes Cluster, which manages a cluster’s …
Flyte can execute Ray jobs natively on a Kubernetes Cluster, which manages a virtual cluster’s lifecycle, spin-up, and tear down. It leverages the …
Flyte can execute Spark jobs natively on a Kubernetes Cluster, which manages a virtual cluster’s lifecycle, spin-up, and tear down. It leverages the …
Flyte can integrate with OpenAI SDKs in your Flyte workflows. It provides drop-in replacements for OpenAI SDKs like openai-agents so that you can build …
In this example, we will use the openai-agents library to create a simple agent that can use tools to perform tasks. This example is based on the basic tools …
This section contains tutorials that showcase relevant use cases and provide step-by-step instructions on how to implement various features using Flyte and …

We welcome contributions to the docs and examples for both Flyte and Union. This section will explain how the docs site works, how to author and build it …
$ brew install hugo A preferences override file with your configuration The tool is flexible and has multiple knobs. Please review hugo.local.toml~sample, and …
The docs site supports the ability to show or hide content based of the current variant selection. There are separate mechanisms for:
In addition to the product variants, the docs site also supports multiple versions of the documentation. The version selector is located at the top of the …
This site has special blocks that can be used to generate code for Union.
We use Cloudflare’s Bulk Redirect to map URLs that moved to their new location, so the user does not get a 404 using the old link.
Content is located in the content folder.
The docs site is built using the Hugo static site generator. You will need to install it to build the site locally. See Hugo Installation.
You can import Python APIs and host them on the site. To do that you will use the tools/api_generator to parse and create the appropriate markdown.

The docs site supports the ability to show or hide content based of the current variant selection. There are separate mechanisms for:
In addition to the product variants, the docs site also supports multiple versions of the documentation. The version selector is located at the top of the …
This site has special blocks that can be used to generate code for Union.
We use Cloudflare’s Bulk Redirect to map URLs that moved to their new location, so the user does not get a 404 using the old link.
Content is located in the content folder.
The docs site is built using the Hugo static site generator. You will need to install it to build the site locally. See Hugo Installation.
You can import Python APIs and host them on the site. To do that you will use the tools/api_generator to parse and create the appropriate markdown.
